User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the Poli Fit Tracker application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

googleId.description: The user's Google ID, obtained from Google authentication.

isAdmin.description: Whether the user is an admin.

Workout.title: Workout
Workout.description: Represents a workout session logged by a user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the workout entity.

startTime.description: The start time of the workout.

endTime.description: The end time of the workout.

duration.description: The duration of the workout in minutes.

photo1Url.description: URL of the first verification photo stored in Firebase Storage.

photo2Url.description: URL of the second verification photo stored in Firebase Storage.

photo1Timestamp.description: Timestamp of when the first verification photo was taken.

photo2Timestamp.description: Timestamp of when the second verification photo was taken.

status.description: The approval status of the workout.

reviewerName.description: Name of the admin who reviewed the workout.

reviewedAt.description: Timestamp of when the workout was reviewed.

definition.description: Stores user profile information. The userId parameter is the Firebase Authentication UID.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user, matching the Firebase Auth UID.

definition.description: Stores workout data for a specific user. This structure establishes clear ownership. Includes denormalized 'userId' to avoid parent `get()` calls in security rules.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user who owns the workout.

params.name: workoutId
params.description: The unique identifier for the workout.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore data structure is designed for security and scalability. User data is stored in `/users/{userId}`. Workouts are stored as a subcollection under each user (`/users/{userId}/workouts/{workoutId}`) to establish clear ownership and simplify security rules. Instead of storing photo files in a separate collection, the direct URLs to the images in Firebase Storage are stored within the workout document (`photo1Url`, `photo2Url`). This simplifies data retrieval, as a single document read fetches all necessary information for a workout, including its verification images. This design follows path-based ownership and ensures efficient, secure queries.
